title: Zelig
brief_description: A fictional documentary about the life of human chameleon Leonard Zelig, a man who becomes a celebrity in the 1920s due to his ability to look and act like whoever is around him.

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

description: Writer and director Woody Allen and Oscar-nominated Cinematographer Gordon Willis employed blue screen technology to combine scratched up and ‘aged’ footage with vintage newsreels of the 1920s and ‘30s in which they inserted the fictional character of Leonard Zelig (Allen) – a man suffering from ‘chameleon disorder’ – in a technically and thematically inventive faux documentary that anticipated digital technology by almost a decade. A thoughtful meditation on the nature of American society and individuality, Allen toyed with several alternate titles for his film, including ‘Identity Crisis and its Relationship to Personality Disorder’.
